an5.156:3.1: 156 The Decline of the True Teaching (3)
an5.156:4.1: “Mendicants, these five things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5.156:4.3: It’s when the mendicants memorize discourses that they learned incorrectly, with misplaced words and phrases.
an5.156:4.4: When the words and phrases are misplaced, the meaning is misinterpreted.
an5.156:4.5: This is the first thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5.156:5.1: Furthermore, the mendicants are hard to correct, having qualities that make them hard to correct. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
an5.156:6.1: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the Vinaya, and the outlines—don’t carefully make others recite the discourses.
an5.156:6.2: When they pass away, the discourses are cut off at the root, with no-one to preserve them.
an5.156:7.1: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5.156:7.2: Those who come after them follow their example.
an5.156:7.3: They too are indulgent and slack …
an5.156:8.1: Furthermore, there’s a schism in the Saṅgha.
an5.156:8.2: When the Saṅgha is split, they abuse, insult, block, and reject each other.
an5.156:8.3: This doesn’t inspire confidence in those without it, and it causes some with confidence to change their minds.
an5.156:8.4: This is the fifth thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5.156:8.5: These five things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5.156:9.1: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5.156:9.3: It’s when the mendicants memorize discourses that have been learned correctly, with well placed words and phrases.
an5.156:9.4: When the words and phrases are well organized, the meaning is correctly interpreted.
an5.156:9.5: This is the first thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5.156:10.1: Furthermore, the mendicants are easy to correct, having qualities that make them easy to correct. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
an5.156:11.1: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the Vinaya, and the outlines—carefully make others recite the discourses.
an5.156:11.2: When they pass away, the discourses aren’t cut off at the root, and they have someone to preserve them.
an5.156:12.1: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5.156:12.2: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5.156:12.3: Those who come after them follow their example.
an5.156:12.4: They too are not indulgent or slack …
an5.156:13.1: Furthermore, the Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without fighting, with one recitation.
an5.156:13.2: When the Saṅgha is in harmony, they don’t abuse, insult, block, or reject each other.
an5.156:13.3: This inspires confidence in those without it, and increases confidence in those who have it.
an5.156:13.4: This is the fifth thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5.156:13.5: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”
